Designer of the [[iMac]], [[iPod]], [[iPhone]], and [[iPad]] | occupation = [[Industrial design]]er | spouse = {{marriage|Heather Pegg|1987}} | awards = [[List of awards and nominations received by Jony Ive|List of awards and nominations]] | module = {{Infobox officeholder | embed = yes | office = Chancellor of the [[Royal College of Art]] | term_start = 1 July 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[James Dyson]] (as Provost) }} }} '''Sir Jonathan Paul''' "'''Jony'''" '''Ive''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KBE|HonFREng|RDI|sep=,|size=small}} (born 27 February 1967) is a British [[industrial design|industrial]], [[product design|product]] and [[Architectural designer|architectural]] designer and former [[Chief Design Officer]] (CDO) of [[Apple Inc.]], now the serving [[Chancellor#Educational_usage|Chancellor]] of the [[Royal College of Art]] in London. He joined Apple in September 1992, where he remained until his departure in November 2019. Following several years of designing Apple products, he was promoted to Senior Vice President of Industrial Design in the late 1990s after the return of co-founder [[Steve Jobs]] to the company, and CDO in 2015. Working closely with Jobs during their tenure together at Apple, Ive played a vital role in the designs of the [[iMac]], [[Power Mac G4 Cube]], [[iPod]], [[iPhone]], [[iPad]], [[MacBook]], and parts of the user interface of Apple's mobile [[operating system]] [[iOS]], among other products. He also helped design Apple's major architectural projects, such as [[Apple Park]] and [[Apple Stores]]. Born in [[London]], England, Ive lived there until his family moved to [[Stafford]] when he was 12. He studied design at [[Northumbria University]],{{Efn|When Ive attended the university in the late-1980s, it was called "Newcastle Polytechnic"}} and was later hired by the London-based start-up design firm Tangerine.{{Cite web|url=https://tangerine.net/jony-ive-apple-designer-started-career-tangerine-set-studio/|title=Jony Ive, Apple designer who started career at tangerine, sets up studio|date=2019-07-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720171112/https://tangerine.net/jony-ive-apple-designer-started-career-tangerine-set-studio/|access-date=2019-07-20|archive-date=20 July 2019}} He began working at Apple in the early 1990s, designing the decade's [[PowerBook]]s and [[Macintosh|Macs]], finally taking up US citizenship in 2012 to become a dual British-American national. He was invited to join the Royal College of Art in May 2017 as its head-of-college, serving a fixed five-year term until May 2022. Ive has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Jony Ive|a number of accolades and honours]] for his designs and patents. In the United Kingdom, he has been appointed a [[Royal Designers for Industry|Royal Designer for Industry]] (RDI), an [[Royal Academy of Engineering|Honorary Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering]] (HonFREng), and a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (KBE). In 2018, he was awarded the Professor Hawking Fellowship. In a 2004 [[BBC]] poll of cultural writers, Ive was ranked the most influential person in [[Culture of the United Kingdom|British culture]]. His designs have been described as integral to the successes of Apple, which has gone on to become the world's largest information technology company by revenue and the largest company in the world by market capitalization. On 27 June 2019, in an exclusive interview with the ''[[Financial Times]]'', Ive announced he would leave Apple after 27 years to start his own design firm, ''LoveFrom,'' together with industrial designer [[Marc Newson]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-48795057.stm|title=iPhone designer Ive to leave Apple|date=27 June 2019|accessdate=27 June 2019|work=BBC News}}{{Cite Ago|first=Tripp|last=Mickle|website=WSJ}}{{Cite journal|url=https://www.wired.com/story/jony-ive-leaves-apple/|title=Jony Ive Is Leaving Apple|journal=Wired|via=www.wired.com}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/6/27/18761736/jony-ive-apple-leave-iphone-chief-design-officer-lovefrom-company-quit|title=Jony Ive leaving Apple after nearly 30 years to start new design firm|first=Chris|last=Welch|date=27 June 2019|website=The Verge}} ==Early life and education== Jonathan Paul Ive was born on 27 February 1967 in [[Chingford]], London, England.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/apple-design-genius-jonathan-ive|title=A Rare Look at Design Genius Jony Ive: The Man Behind the Apple Watch|last=Sullivan|first=Robert|date=1 October 2014|work=Vogue|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/apple/9283486/Jonathan-Ive-interview-Apples-design-genius-is-British-to-the-core.html|title=Jonathan Ive interview: Apple's design genius is British to the core|last=Richmond|first=Shane|date=23 May 2012|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} His father, Michael Ive, was a [[silversmith]] who lectured at [[Middlesex Polytechnic]], and his grandfather was an engineer. Raised just outside of London, Ive attended the [[Chingford Foundation School]] and [[Walton High School (Stafford)|Walton High School]] in [[Stafford]] where he studied sculpture and chemistry. While attending secondary school, Ive was diagnosed with dyslexia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/the-fabulous-life-of-sir-jony-ive-2014-7|title=The life and rise of Jony Ive, the legendary Apple designer who's now leaving to strike out on his own|last=Aydin|first=Paige Leskin, Rebecca|website=Business Insider|access-date=2019-12-20}} According to a March 2014 interview with ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', "It was his teenage love of cars that made Ive decide to become a designer. When he left school, he checked out a few car-design courses in London, including one at the Royal College. He swiftly changed his mind. 'The classes were full of students making vroom! vroom! noises as they drew,' he recalls, still horrified. So he headed to Newcastle Polytechnic to study industrial design. His work there — notably a telephone and a hearing aid — was so good it was exhibited at the Design Museum in London."{{Cite web|url=https://time.com/jonathan-ive-apple-interview/|title=Apple Designer Jonathan Ive Talks About Steve Jobs and New Products|date=2019-07-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720173949/https://time.com/jonathan-ive-apple-interview/|access-date=2019-07-20|archive-date=20 July 2019}} Ive attended [[Newcastle Polytechnic]] (later renamed [[Northumbria University|University of Northumbria at Newcastle]]) during the late-1980s. While at Newcastle, some of his more notable designs—including a [[hearing aid]] design—were exhibited at the [[Design Museum]] in London. Ive graduated with a [[British undergraduate degree classification|first class]] [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in industrial design in 1989. Ive's designs at polytechnic garnered Ive the RSA Student Design Award, which afforded him a small [[stipend]] and a travel expense account to use on a trip to the United States.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=640f7JNTX0kC&pg=PA343&lpg=PA343&dq=jony+ive+shaved+head#v=onepage|title=The Apple Revolution: Steve Jobs, the Counterculture and How the Crazy Ones Took over the World|last=Dormehl|first=Luke|date=8 August 2012|publisher=Random House|isbn=9781448131365|location=|pages=|language=en}} Ive traveled to [[Palo Alto, California]], where he met with various design experts including [[Robert Brunner]]—a designer who ran a small consultancy firm that would later join [[Apple Inc.|Apple Computers]]. After returning to England six weeks later, Ive [[Internship|interned]] at product design agency Roberts Weaver Group (his college sponsor) where he impressed executives with a pronounced attention to detail and work ethic. ==Career== === Tangerine === After a year with Roberts Weaver, Ive joined the industrials group at a London startup design agency called Tangerine, located in [[Hoxton Square]] where he designed a diverse array of products, such as microwave ovens, toilets, drills and toothbrushes.{{cite web|url=http://time.com/jonathan-ive-apple-interview/|title=Jonathan Ive Designs Tomorrow|author=John Arlidge|date=17 March 2014|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=Time Inc|access-date=1 November 2018}} However, his frustration with the position reached a turning point after he designed a toilet, bidet, and sink for client [[Ideal Standard]], and the company's boss rejected Ive's work, stating that the products were too costly and looked too modern.{{cite web|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About mApple Design Chief Jony Ive|url=http://mashable.com/2013/11/06/jony-ive-biography/|work=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=7 November 2013|author=Seth Fiegerman|date=6 November 2013}} Ive was unhappy working for clients whom he disliked and who had different ideas. From 1990 to 1992, [[Robert Brunner]], as he was ascending the corporate ladder, unsuccessfully attempted to recruit Ive to Apple. During this time, Apple became a client of Tangerine, with Ive spearheading the firm's initial [[PowerBook]] designs. === Apple === File:Apple Newton-IMG 0454-cropped.jpg|[[Apple Newton|Apple Newton MessagePad]], released in 1993. Ive designed the smaller models following File:Ipod 1G.png|First [[iPod]], introduced in 2001. [[Jon Rubinstein]] assembled the original design team including Ive as lead design engineer File:IPhone 1st Gen.svg|A vector render of the 1st generation [[iPhone]], first marketed in 2007. Its [[Form factor (mobile phones)|form factor]] is credited to Ive File:IPad 1 PSD Mockup.png|Although Ive's studio began designing an iPad-like device before the iPhone, the [[iPad]] was first released in 2010 He was formally recruited to Apple as a full-time employee in September 1992. Ive was initially apprehensive about leaving Tangerine for Apple as he thought the move from Britain to California would take a toll on his family. His first major assignment in Apple's industrial design group regarded the second generation of the [[Newton (platform)|Newton]] and the [[MessagePad]] 110. Initial design failures and lack of commercial success during the early 1990s, prompted Ive to nearly quit on multiple occasions. [[Steve Jobs]], who had been ousted by other Apple executives in 1985, was staging a return to the company and recruited Ive to join him in taking the firm in a different direction. [[Jon Rubinstein]], Ive's boss at the time, managed to retain Ive as an employee by explaining that Apple was "going to make history" following the revival of the company in 1996. [[File:IMac Bondi Blue.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Original 1998 [[iMac G3]]]] He became the senior vice president of industrial design in 1997 after the return of Jobs, and subsequently headed the industrial design team responsible for most of the company's significant hardware products. Ive's first design assignment in this capacity was the [[iMac]], introduced in 1998 (he is credited with designing its translucent plastic case). The iMac helped pave the way for many other designs such as the [[iPod]] and eventually the [[iPhone]] and the [[iPad]].{{cite magazine|last=Ohannessian|first=Kevin|title=100 Most Creative People in Business: No. 1 – Jonathan Ive|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/100/2009/jonathan-ive|magazine=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|accessdate=2 January 2012|date=18 May 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111227064856/http://www.fastcompany.com/100/2009/jonathan-ive|archivedate=27 December 2011|df=dmy-all}} Ive explained the close rapport that existed in his working relationship with Jobs in 2014: "When we were looking at objects, what our eyes physically saw and what we came to perceive were exactly the same. And we would ask the same questions, have the same curiosity about things." Ive was given his own design office at Apple during the early 2000s in which he oversees the work of his appointed design team, and he is the only Apple designer with a private office. Only his core team—which consists of around 15 people from the UK, the US, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand (who have worked together for around two decades)—and top Apple executives are allowed into the office, as it contains all of the concepts, including prototypes, that the design team is working on. Ive also refuses to allow his children or family members to enter the office. During the early 2010s, Jobs declared that Ive "has more operational power than anyone else at Apple except me."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/apple/8985289/Apple-designer-becomes-Sir-Jonathan-Ive-in-New-Year-Honours.html|title=Apple designer becomes Sir Jonathan Ive in New Year Honours|last=Richmond|first=Shane|date=31 December 2011|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=15 June 2012|location=London|quote=According to Walter Isaacson's biography of Steve Jobs, the company's late chief executive gave Ive a unique position within the company. Jobs told Isaacson: "He's not just a designer. That's why he works directly for me. He has more operational power than anyone else at Apple except me. There's no one who can tell him what to do, or to butt out. That's the way I set it up."}} The offices of Jobs and Ive in [[Apple Campus|Apple's Cupertino headquarters]] were linked through a hidden, built-in corridor with single-access doors.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/feb/17/apples-jony-ive-digested-23-things-weve-learned|title=Apple's Jony Ive digested: 23 things we've learned|last=Gibbs|first=Samuel|date=17 March 2015|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=1 November 2018}} In 2011 it was reported that Ive was paid $30 million in [[Salary|base salary]] with a $25 million [[Option (finance)|stock bonus]] in total compensation for the year.{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/01/07/apple-jony-ive-compensation/|title=How Much Does Apple Pay Jony Ive?|last=Phillip|first=Elmer-Dewitt|date=6 January 2017|work=Fortune|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en}} His compensation ceased to be publicly disclosed by the firm thereafter, rendering him the only Apple executive to be afforded such as provision. A year later it was estimated that his [[net worth]] was [[Pound sign|£]]80 million. [[File:Aerial view of Apple Park dllu.jpg|thumb|224x224px|Ive played a pivotal role, with [[Norman Foster]], in the design of [[Apple Park]] ''(pictured)'' throughout much of the 2010s, which officially opened in 2017]] On 29 October 2012, Apple announced that Ive would "provide leadership and direction for [[User interface|Human Interface]] (HI) across the company in addition to his role as the leader of Industrial Design."{{cite web|title=Apple Announces Changes to Increase Collaboration Across Hardware, Software & Services |url=https://www.apple.com/pr/library/2012/10/29Apple-Announces-Changes-to-Increase-Collaboration-Across-Hardware-Software-Services.html |accessdate=1 November 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029235405/http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2012/10/29Apple-Announces-Changes-to-Increase-Collaboration-Across-Hardware-Software-Services.html |archivedate=29 October 2012 }} With the 2013 [[Apple Worldwide Developers Conference|World Wide Developers Conference]] (WWDC) announcement of [[iOS 7]] and Ive's role as principal, Apple press information was also updated to reflect his new title: Senior Vice President of Design. In the same press update, Ive stated that he hoped his best work was yet to emerge and that he preferred to be identified as a maker of products, rather than a designer. On 26 May 2015, the firm announced that Ive was promoted to [[chief design officer]] (CDO), at the time one of only three [[List of corporate titles|C-level executives]] at Apple along with CEO [[Tim Cook]] and CFO [[Luca Maestri]] ([[Jeff Williams (Apple)|Jeff Williams]] would be promoted to COO at the end of 2015).{{cite web|title=Jony Ive promoted to 'Chief Design Officer,' handing off managerial duties July 1st [Tim Cook Memo]|url=http://9to5mac.com/2015/05/25/jony-ive-chief-design-officer/|website=9to5Mac|date=25 May 2015|accessdate=28 May 2015}} On 8 December 2017, Apple announced that Ive would resume direct responsibility for the company's product design after spending the preceding two years in a more executive, non-creative role.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-08/apple-s-ive-regains-management-of-design-team-after-2-years|title=Apple's Ive Regains Management of Design Team After 2 Years|last=Gurman|first=Mark|date=8 December 2017|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=1 November 2018}} Apple announced on 27 June 2019 that Ive would depart the company, stating that he would start an independent firm titled LoveFrom, along with fellow Apple industrial designer [[Marc Newson]], that would work with Apple as its primary client.{{cite news |last=Leswing |first=Kif |date=27 June 2019 |title=Apple's chief design officer, Jony Ive, is leaving the company |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/27/apples-chief-design-officer-jony-ive-is-leaving-the-company.html |publisher=CNBC News |accessdate=27 June 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2019/07/01/tim-cook-jony-ive-report/|title=Tim Cook slams WSJ report on Jony Ive's departure from Apple as 'absurd'|first=Chance|last=Miller|date=1 July 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/947e557a-98a8-11e9-8cfb-30c211dcd229|title=Jony Ive, iPhone designer, announces Apple departure|first=Tim|last=Bradshaw|date=27 June 2019|website=Financial Times}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidphelan/2019/06/29/jony-ives-shock-departure-from-apple-what-does-it-really-mean/|title=Jony Ive's Shock Departure From Apple |first=David|last=Phelan|website=Forbes}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2019/06/jony-ive-to-form-independent-design-company-with-apple-as-client/|title=Jony Ive to form independent design company with Apple as client|website=Apple Newsroom}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rachelsandler/2019/06/27/apples-top-designer-jony-ive-to-leave-after-30-years/|title=Apple's Top Designer Jony Ive To Leave After Nearly 30 Years|first=Rachel|last=Sandler|website=Forbes}} === Royal College of Art === Ive received an honorary degree from the [[Royal College of Art]] (RCA) in 2009. On 25 May 2017, it was announced that Ive was appointed Chancellor of the RCA in London effective 1 July 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/jony-ive-apples-chief-design-officer-appointed-chancellor-of-royal-college-of-art-2017-5?r=UK&IR=T|title=Sir Jony Ive has been appointed chancellor of the world's number 1 art school|last=Saheed|first=Sam|date=25 May 2017|work=Business Insider|access-date=25 May 2017|language=en}} In this position he serves a fixed five-year term as the Head of College, where he will govern the college as an [[Academic administration|academic administrator]]. Ive began running committee meetings, attending faculty meetings, and conferring graduate degrees in the summer of 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/991920/apple-design-chief-jony-ive-has-been-appointed-as-the-new-chancellor-of-londons-royal-college-of-art/|title=Apple design chief Jony Ive is the new chancellor of the world's best design school|last=Quito|first=Anne|date=25 May 2017|work=Quartz|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en-US}} Ive said of the appointment: "I am thrilled to formalise my relationship with the RCA, given the profound influence the college has had on so many of the artists and designers that I admire."{{Cite web|url=https://www.rca.ac.uk/news-and-events/news/sir-jony-ive-kbe-appointed-chancellor-royal-college-art/|title=Sir Jony Ive KBE Appointed Chancellor of the Royal College of Art|date=25 May 2017|website=Royal College of Art|access-date=1 November 2018}} == Public image == [[File:Ive Lasseter.jpg|thumb|Ive with [[John Lasseter]] at the opening of [[Macworld Expo]] in 2008]] Ive is widely known for his minimalist, downplayed sense of style and presentation of self.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailydot.com/unclick/my-night-with-jonathan-ive/|title=My night with Sir Jonathan Ive at a London nightclub|last=Kramer|first=Nimrod|date=18 July 2014|work=The Daily Dot|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en-US}} Chief among his public image is his "nearly shaved head and tightly trimmed beard". It is estimated that Ive first shaved his head in a [[Buzz cut|tight buzzcut]] and coupled it with [[Designer stubble|stubble]] in 2001, aged 34, after he was promoted to vice president of industrial design at Apple.{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/2014/09/09/the-evolution-of-jony/#QL9raBKznqqi|title=The Evolution of Apple's Jony Ive|last=Koerber|first=Brian|date=9 September 2014|work=Mashable|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en}} His look had him referred to as one of the "100 Most Powerful Bald Men in the World" by [[GQ]] in their 2013 listing.{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/gallery/the-100-most-powerful-bald-men-in-world|title=The 100 Most Powerful Bald Men in the World|last=Geller|first=Sarah|date=16 July 2013|work=GQ|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en}} Known for its minimalist look, it has inspired [[Halloween costume]]s,{{Cite web|url=https://thescene.com/watch/wired/10-halloween-costumes-for-geeks|title=10 Halloween Costumes For Geeks|website=WIRED Videos|access-date=1 November 2018}} grooming regimens, and a small-scale fashion movement, among other things.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/may/23/in-praise-of-sir-jonathan-ive-editorial|title=In praise of … Sir Jonathan Ive|last=Editorial|date=23 May 2012|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=1 November 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/htc-has-its-own-jony-ive/|title=Hey, look! HTC's designer looks just like Apple's Jony Ive|last=Van Camp|first=Jeffery|date=5 January 2013|work=Digital Trends|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en-US}} He has been known to sport "signature looks" that include: multi-colored ''[[Houndstooth|pied-de-poule]]'' suits,{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/20aad4d4-d2ba-11e8-a9f2-7574db66bcd5|title=Jony Ive on the Apple Watch and Big Tech's responsibilities|last=Foulkes|first=Nicholas|date=19 October 2018|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|access-date=1 November 2018}} painter's pants, canvas pants,{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/jonathan-ive-apple-interview/|title=Apple Designer Jonathan Ive Gives Rare, Remarkable Interview|last=Arlidge|first=John|date=17 March 2014|website=TIME.com|access-date=1 November 2018}} linen [[Dress shirt|button down]] shirts, [[C. & J. Clark|Clarks Wallabees]], and mono-colored [[t-shirt]]s. His favorite tailor is reportedly British clothier [[Thomas_Mahon_(tailor)|Thomas Mahon]]. Ive's voice, used in [[Apple Inc. advertising|Apple's marketing and promotional videos]] since 1994, has been noted for its [[Regional accents of English#British Isles|Essex accent]] and reserved, [[wiktionary:loquacious|loquacious]] style of speech.{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/apple/2015/09/11/thats-sir-jonathan-paul-ive-to-you/|title=Now you can make Jony Ive say 'aluminium' whenever you want|last=Connolly|first=Amanda|date=11 November 2015|work=The Next Web|access-date=1 November 2018|language=en-US}}{{Citation|last=Think Multiply|title=Jony Ive's magical voice for Apple marketing|date=19 January 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ydkvO6C9pTs|volume=|pages=|access-date=1 November 2018}} == Influences == The work and principles of [[Dieter Rams]], the chief designer at [[Braun (company)|Braun]] from 1961 until 1995, influenced Ive's work. In [[Gary Hustwit]]'s documentary film ''[[Objectified]]'' (2009), Rams says that Apple is one of only a handful of companies existing today that design products according to [[Dieter Rams#"Good design" principles|his ten principles of good design]].{{cite web|url=http://www.braun.com/global/world-of-braun/braun-design/design-evolution.html|title=Design evolution|year=2009|publisher=Braun GmbH|accessdate=24 May 2011|quote=Designer: Dieter Rams and Dietrich Lubs}}{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/343641/1960s-braun-products-hold-the-secrets-to-apples-future|title=The Future of Apple Is in 1960s Braun: 1960s ''Braun Products Hold the Secrets to Apple's Future''|date=14 January 2008|publisher=gizmodo.com (Gawker Media)|accessdate=30 June 2010}} He is also said to have been influenced by the [[Bauhaus]] tradition (known for its credos [[form follows function]] and [[less is more (architecture)|less is more]]), which emerged in Germany during the 1920s and became a staple design approach adopted by the [[Ulm School of Design]] during the 1950s. The Bauhaus / Ulm design style was also adopted during the 1980s by luxury automotive brand [[Audi]], which also influenced Jonathan Ive's designs (particularly his work with Apple), and has garnered comparisons in [[Stencil|color stencil]], structure, and [[Lighting designer|lighting design]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2013/11/30/jony-ives-no-longer-so-secret-design-weapon/#da920fd3f62c|title=Jony Ive's No Longer So Secret Design Weapon|work=Forbes}}{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/343641/1960s-braun-products-hold-the-secrets-to-apples-future|title=Braun Products Hold The Secrets To Apple's Future|work=Gizmodo}} == Personal life == While he was attending secondary school at [[Walton High School (Stafford)|Walton High School]] in [[Stafford]] he met his future wife, British writer and historian Heather Pegg Ive in 1987. He and Pegg have two sons. His family resides in the [[Pacific Heights, San Francisco|Pacific Heights]] neighbourhood of San Francisco, California. Their home retailed for [[United States dollar|US$]]17.0 million in 2014. Ive commutes an hour and a half from San Francisco to [[Apple Park|Apple's headquarters]] in [[Cupertino, California|Cupertino]] every day. According to the ''[[Sunday Times Rich List]]'' in 2019, Ive is worth £192 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/sunday-times-rich-list-2019-profiles-602-650-sting-rod-stewart-7v729g2dj|title=Rich List 2019: profiles 602-650, featuring Sting and Sir Rod Stewart|last=Times|first=The Sunday|date=2019-05-12|access-date=2019-11-20|language=en|issn=0140-0460}} Known to live a reserved, private home life, he shuns publicity. He explained in 2014 that if his work at Apple ever became substandard, he would "make things for [himself], for [his] friends at home instead". === Automobiles === Since his early years in England, Ive has expressed an interest in automobiles and [[automotive design]]. While in university he drove a [[Fiat 500]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jony-ive-favorite-cars-2015-2#ive-used-to-own-an-aston-martin-db9-but-he-crashed-it-near-san-bruno-california-3|title=Apple designer Jony Ive's favorite cars|last=Colt|first=Sam|date=14 February 2015|work=Business Insider|access-date=1 November 2018}} He frequently attends [[auto show]]s and exhibitions such as the [[Goodwood Festival of Speed]], where he serves as a [[Jury|jury member]] for competitions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/apples-jony-ive-talks-cars-at-goodwood-2016-7|title=Here's rare video of Apple designer Jony Ive talking about a gorgeous Ferrari|last=Lewsig|first=Kif|date=17 July 2016|work=Business Insider|access-date=1 November 2018}} It has been reported that Ive's preferred [[Automotive industry|automobile manufacturers]] were all British: [[Aston Martin]], [[Bentley]], and [[Land Rover]]. Ive has been linked to owning a wide-variety of automobiles including: an [[Aston Martin DB4]], [[Aston Martin DB9]], [[Aston Martin Vanquish]], [[Bentley Brooklands]], [[Bentley Mulsanne (2010)|Bentley Mulsanne]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/transportation/2015/2/16/8045625/jony-ive-apple-modern-car-design-is-shocking|title=Jony Ive laments 'shocking' state of modern car design|last=Vincent|first=James|date=16 February 2015|work=The Verge|access-date=1 November 2018}} [[Land Rover Discovery|Land Rover LR3]], and a [[Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud]]. ==Charity work== Ive has designed products for charitable causes, including a [[Leica camera]] for a charity auction that set a world record auction price for a camera{{cite web|title=Leica camera sets a new digital record|url=http://britishphotohistory.ning.com/profiles/blogs/leica-camera-sets-a-new-record|work=British Photographic History|publisher=Michael Pritchard|accessdate=22 March 2014|author=Michael Pritchard|date=24 November 2013}} and a [[Jaeger-LeCoultre]] sports watch—one of only three in the world—for an [[HIV/AIDS]]-charity auction. During this auction, Ive (and [[Marc Newson]]) raised $13.0 million for [[Bono]]'s [[Product Red]] charity. ==Honours and awards== {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Jony Ive}} Throughout his career as an [[industrial design]]er at Tangerine and Apple, Ive has received nominations and garnered awards for his body of work.
